titleStmt.title: Walters Ms. W.599, The lights of Canopus
Anvār-i Suhaylī
انوار سهيلى

title.note: Title appears on fol. 5a, line 1, and in the colophon

author.name: Kāshifī, Ḥusayn Vāʻiẓ, d. 1504 or 5
Ḥusayn ibn ʿAlī Vāʿiẓ Kāshifī
حسين بن على واعظ كاشفى
Author dates preferred by cataloger: d. 910 AH / 1504-5 CE

respStmt.name: Mīrzā Raḥīm navādah-i Mīrzā Amīn Afshār
ميرزا رحيم نواده ميرزا امين افشار

availability.p: Licensed for use under Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported Access Rights, http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/legalcode. It is requested that copies of any published articles based on the information in this data set be sent to the curator of manuscripts, The Walters Art Museum, 600 North Charles Street, Baltimore MD 21201.

notesStmt.note: This is an illuminated and illustrated copy of Anvār-i Suhaylī (The lights of Canopus), dating to the thirteenth century AH / nineteenth CE. It is a Persian version of Kalīlah wa-Dimnah (The fables of Bīdpāy). It was completed on 26 Jumādá I 1264 AH / 1847 CE by Mīrzā Raḥīm. The text is written in nastaʿliq script in black and red ink, revealing the influence of shikastah script. There are 123 paintings illustrating the text. The Qajar binding is original to the manuscript.

msContents.textLang: The primary language in this manuscript is Persian.

msItem.title: Anvār-i Suhaylī
انوار سهيلى

title.note: Title appears on fol. 5a, line 1, and in the colophon

msItem.incipit: حضرت حكيم على الاطلاق جلت حكمته كه...

colophon.note: tamām shud Kitāb-i Anvār-i Suhaylī bi-ʿawn Allāh Taʿālá va-ḥusn tawfīqih dar rūz-i dū shanbah bīst va-shashum /1/ shahr-i Jumādá al-avval 1264 itmām paḏīraft katabahu Mīrzā Raḥīm navādah-i Mīrzā Amīn Afshār /2/
Gives the name of the scribe and the date of copying

layoutDesc.layout: Framing lines in blue, black, and gold

handDesc.handNote: Written in nastaʿliq script, influenced by shikastah script, in black and red ink

decoDesc.decoNote: One hundred twenty-three illustrations; incipit page with illuminated headpiece (fol. 1b); framing lines in blue, black, and gold

decoNote.title: Incipit page with illuminated headpiece
A scholar
decoNote.note: This illustration depicts a scholar (perhaps Barzūyah, the physician of Nūshirwān, who deputed the author to seek the work known to us as the Fables of Bīdpāy).

decoNote.title: King Humāyūn Fāl hunting in the company of his vizier, Khujastah Rāy
Two pigeons, Bāzandah and Navāzandah
Two hawks and a crow’s nest
An old woman’s cat in the courtyard being shot by an archer
A poor father and his son
An old merchant advising his three sons
The king of Ḥalab (Aleppo) and his two sons
A farmer’s corn supply being attacked by mice
A monkey and a carpenter
Ghānim, his friend Salīm, and a stone lion near a river
A fox and a drum
A king and a dervish
A shoemaker and his unfaithful wife
Two sparrows set on fire and a falcon
A despotic king, a dog, a fox, a man, and a horse, all with maimed legs
A snake and a crow’s chicks
A heron, a crab, and a fish
A jackal devours a hare
An evil lion, tricked by a hare, looks into a well and sees his reflection
Two fishermen and three fishes
A tortoise carries a scorpion on its back across a river
A goose and a reflection of the moon in the water
A hawk and a hen
A gardener and a nightingale
A leopard devouring the hunter of a fox
A lion, a crow, a wolf, two jackals, and a rabbit devouring a camel
Tīṭawá birds of India, a tortoise, and ducks
A sīmurgh and an army of birds attacks the spirit of the ocean
A lion king devours the ox Shanzabah
A man, five monkeys, and a bird
Two associates, the shrewd and the careless, on horseback
A frog, a snake, and a crab
A confrontation between a lawyer and his party and a man who was hiding in a hollow tree
A gardener and a bear
A bear trying to kill flies on a gardener’s face with a large rock
A merchant and a friend to whom the merchant entrusted some iron
A hungry fox, a jackal, and a piece of hide
A donkey without a tail
A king and his equerry readying for a race
A king and a holy man meeting in front of a cave
A blind man holds a snake that he has mistakenly taken for his whip
A dervish, mistaken for a thief and about to be beheaded, is saved by an old shaykh
A Kashmiri merchant and his two wives
A merchant’s unfaithful wife in the company of her lover’s slave
Three envious men with a sack of gold are questioned by a king
Three envious men being executed on the order of the king
The Lord of the Marches and his falconer slave from Balkh
A falcon plucks out the eye of a liar servant in the presence of the Lord of the Marches and his wife
A mouse named Zīrak gnaws at a net to free pigeons
A partridge and a hawk
A snake, saved by a camel driver, threatens to bite him
A crow brings a mouse to see its tortoise friend
A man in conversation with his wife and a wolf
decoNote.note: These illustrations depict a man in conversation with his wife about amassing wealth and a wolf about to feast on a hunter, a deer the hunter killed, and a boar that killed the hunter.

decoNote.title: A greedy cat killed by the owner of pigeons
A deer, a crow, and a mouse rescue their tortoise friend caught in a net
Owls fight crows
The king of Kashmir, his favorite wife, and a youthful attendant
A flock of birds comes together to elect a leader
Four elephants in search of water come to a place inhabited by hares
A partridge and a quail in the company of an old cat
An old cat kills a partridge and a quail
Three robbers
decoNote.note: This illustration depicts three robbers trying to steal the sheep from a holy man by trying to convince him that he had bought a dog instead.

decoNote.title: A rich merchant and his wife being robbed while sleeping
Two robbers and a demon try to kill a holy man to steal his buffalo
A carpenter’s wife and her lover are spied on by the carpenter who hides under the bed
A group of monkeys attacked by four bears
A holy man
decoNote.note: This illustration depicts a holy man who turns a mouse (brought by a crow) into a girl and hands her over to his disciple to be raised.

decoNote.title: The son of a holy man lies dead, bitten by a snake
A snake who used to eat the young of sparrows being burned in a fire
A king and his son in the company of other relations
A king, a monkey, and a tortoise
A faithful monkey struggles with a robber in the presence of the sleeping king
A monkey rides on the back of a swimming tortoise
A lion attacks an ass belonging to a laundryman who was deceived by a fox
A holy man and his pregnant wife discuss the future of their baby
A holy man is puzzled after having killed the faithful weasel who killed a snake to protect the holy man's infant son
A king holding a dead falcon is offered a cup of water poisoned by a dead dragon
A mouse tries to release a cat caught in a net while a crow seated on a tree waits in ambush
A lion attacks the unfaithful wife of an old man while her lover on horseback runs away
A mouse gnaws at a net to release a cat caught in it
A crow catches a mouse and a frog who had tied themselves together by a cord as a sign of friendship
King Ibn Madīn and his son, whose eyes were plucked out after he killed the young of the king’s favorite lark
A group of thieves
decoNote.note: This illustration depicts a group of thieves plotting against a dervish from Raqqah called Dānādil on his way to Mecca while a flock of cranes flies over.

decoNote.title: An old woman and her cow
decoNote.note: This illustration depicts an old woman speaking to her cow with a pot on its head. She mistook the cow for an angel of death come for her and instead instructs it to take her daughter Muhastī.

decoNote.title: A jealous court musician, about to be executed, pleads his case for killing the king's favorite slave, also a musician
A physician attending to a sick man
The king of Turkistān and his courtiers
A holy man admonishes a wolf for his wicked designs on men’s sheep
An Arab of the desert in a Baghdad bakery angers the baker by eating more bread than he paid for
The jackal Farīsah converses with the lion king Kāmjū’ī
A dervish chases flies away from a honey pot with a fan
The ruler of Baghdad and his beautiful Chinese slave girl are entertained by musicians
A Chinese slave girl is lead away to be executed
A slave of an envious Baghdad merchant
decoNote.note: This illustration depicts a slave of an envious Baghdad merchant who kills the merchant on the roof belonging to a holy man to put the blame on the latter.

decoNote.title: An impoverished chamberlain of the king of Yemen steals a golden goblet
A lion and a jackal
A hunter with a lion, a jackal, and other animals
A tyrant buys a bundle of wood from a poor man in the presence of a reproaching holy man
An old monkey on a fig tree is visited by a boar who demands a share of the fruit
A European traveler visits a holy man of Qinnawj
A bleacher saves a crane
An older wife plucks out the black hairs from her husband’s beard in the presence of his younger wife
A hunter shares his catch with two students according to his promise
A crow admires the way a partridge walks and imitates its gait
King Solomon in the company of an angel, his courtiers, animals, birds, and a demon
King Hīlār of India and his wife Irān-dukht
King Hīlār of India, his wife Irān-dukht, and his concubine Bazm Afrūz
A king comes to consult a holy man after having accidentally killed a poor woodcutter
A treacherous maid lies dead after having been forced to ingest the poison she had prepared for her queen
Two pigeons and a supply of grain
The king of Ḥalab (Aleppo), his daughter, the vizier, and a goldsmith
The king of Fārs buys a slave from a merchant, not knowing that the slave is his son
A merchant’s daughter brings her jewels to the princess
A traveler is saved by a monkey
A traveler cures the princess and a malicious goldsmith is crucified
A prince with three companions
A butcher kills a cow for a peasant and his wife to be distributed as alms
A prince and his companions
Two hoopoes freed by an old man show him a box full of jewels

binding.p: Lacquer boards (no flap); decorated with flowers and birds

history.acquisition: Walters Art Museum, 1931, by Henry Walters bequest
